front.title: Network Time Protocol (NTP) Server Option for DHCPv6

abstract.t: The NTP Server Option for Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol for IPv6 (DHCPv6) provides NTP (Network Time Protocol version 4) Server location information to DHCPv6 hosts. This document obsoletes .

section.title: Introduction
section.t: This document defines a DHCPv6 option to provide Network Time Protocol version 4 or greater Server location information to DHCPv6 hosts.

section.title: Requirements notation
section.t: The key words "MUST", "MUST NOT", "REQUIRED", "SHALL", "SHALL NOT", "SHOULD", "SHOULD NOT", "RECOMMENDED", "MAY", and "OPTIONAL" in this document are to be interpreted as described in .

section.title: Related Work and Usage Model
section.t: The NTP service is publicly offered on the Internet by a number of organizations. Those Servers can be used but should not be abused, so any method which is tasked to disseminate locations of NTP Servers must act responsibly in a manner that does not lead to public Server overloading. When using DHCPv6 to offer NTP Server location, and if there is a need to distribute a host with a hardcoded configuration, this configuration MUST NOT include Server location that is not part of the organization that distributes this device. Typical usage of this option is to specify an NTP Server that is part of the organization that operates the DHCPv6 Server.

The location of the NTP service, like any other Internet service, can be specified by an IP address or a Fully Qualified Domain Name (FQDN). By design, DHCP offers information to multiple devices and is prone to amplification of mistakes, so great care must be taken to define its configuration. Specification of the NTP service by FQDN offers a level of indirection that works as a possible mitigation tool in case of misconfiguration. DNS can be used to redirect misconfigured clients to an IPv6 address that is not configured on any host instead of having to change the address of the NTP Server itself.

While the NTP specification defines a comprehensive set of configuration parameters, modification of those parameters is best left to the decision of the client itself. The DHCPv6 option for NTP is therefore restricted to Server location.

section.title: NTP Server Option for DHCPv6
section.t: The option carries the NTP Server or SNTP Server FQDN.

If the NTP Server or SNTP Server location is an IPv6 multicast address, the client SHOULD use this address as an NTP multicast group address and listen to messages sent to this group in order to synchronize its clock.

This document does not define any priority relationship between the client's embedded configuration (if any) and the NTP or SNTP Servers discovered via this option. In particular, the client is allowed to simultaneously use its own configured NTP Servers or SNTP Servers and the Servers discovered via DHCP.
This option specifies the FQDN of an NTP Server or SNTP Server available to the client.

section.title: Issues with RFC5908
section.t: This document obsoletes and defines replacement option. The following list enumerates problems with RFC5908 approach:

list.t: It is redundant to have 3 ways to specify the same thing.

It defined 3 separate sub-options: one for unicast or anycast address, second for multicast address and third one for FQDN option. Even though it forbade to mix them within one NTP server option, it allowed to send multiple instances of that option, effectively allowing mix and match of those types.

Specifying separate option for multicast address when there is a unicast address option does not make sense. It would be better to specify one option to send an address and allow both unicast and multicast in it. It is trivial check if the received address is multicast (first octet is ff) or unicast (first octet is not ff).

FQDN and address options have different usage models. An address is consumed as is and its value does not change over time, unless updated information is received during renewal or rebind events. On the other hand, FQDN usage depends on when it is resolved. If it is resolved immediately upon reception by the client, then it is almost equal to address (FQDN can resolve to both IPv4 and IPv6 addresses, and can resolve to more than one address). However, typical FQDN usage model is that it is stored as FQDN and later resolved when NTP configuration is needed. This has the benefit of operator being able to change name resolution to a different NTP server without needing to update clients configuration. Please note the different timescales of receiving an address and receiving FQDN that is resolved many times. Those two are incompatible and can't be merged easily.

Client is allowed to send the NTP option (the option itself, not its code in ORO) in SOLICIT, REQUEST, RENEW, REBIND and INFORMATION-REQUEST. The text does not explain why client may do that or what the server is supposed to do with received values. It is unclear if the client should send empty NTP option or with sub-options, which sub-options and with what values.
It violates many DHCPv6 rules and it never completed DHC review. Currently the rules for defining options are specified in .
Nits: There are no server behavior or client behavior sections, so it is unclear what each entity is supposed to do.

section.title: DHCPv6 Server Behavior
section.t: Sections 17.2.2 and 18.2 of govern server operation in regards to option assignment. As a convenience to the reader, we mention here that the server will send option NTP Option only if configured with specific values for NTP Option and the client requested it.

section.title: DHCPv6 Client Behavior
section.t: Clients MAY request NTP Server Option, as defined in , sections 17.1.1, 18.1.1, 18.1.3, 18.1.4, 18.1.5 and 22.7. As a convenience to the reader, we mention here that the client includes requested option codes in Option Request Option.

Optional text (if the option contains FQDN): If the client requests an option that conveys an FQDN, it is expected that the contents of that option will be resolved using DNS. Hence the following text may be useful: Clients that request option foo SHOULD also request option OPTION_DNS_SERVERS specified in .
Clients MUST discard option foo if it is invalid (i.e. did not pass validation steps defined in Section X.Y).

section.title: Appearance of this Option
section.t: The OPTION_NTP_SERVER option can appear multiple times in a DHCPv6 message. The order in which these options appear is not significant. The client uses its usual algorithms to determine which Server(s) or multicast group(s) should be prefered to synchronize its clock.

The OPTION_NTP_SERVER option MUST NOT appear in messages other than the following: Solicit, Advertise, Request, Renew, Rebind, Information-Request, and Reply. If this option appears in messages other than those specified above, the receiver MUST ignore it.

The option number for this option MAY appear in the "Option Request" option in the following messages: Solicit, Request, Renew, Rebind, Information-Request, and Reconfigure. If this option number appears in the "Option Request" option in messages other than those specified above, the receiver SHOULD ignore it.

section.title: Security Considerations
section.t: This option could be used by an intruder to advertise the address of a malicious NTP Server or SNTP Server and adversely affect the clock of clients on the network. The consequences of such an attack can be critical, because many security protocols depend on time synchronization to run their algorithms. As an example, an attacker could break connectivity between SEND-enabled nodes , simply by affecting the clock on these nodes.
To prevent these attacks, it is strongly advisable to secure the use of this option either by:

list.t: using the NTPv4 Autokey public key authentication, as defined in or,
using authenticated DHCP as described in section 21.

section.title: RFC 4075 Deprecation
section.t: (SNTP Configuration Option for DHCPv6) provides some degree of automatic time Server configuration for IPv6, as it specifies how to transmit SNTP Servers addresses through DHCPv6. However this approach is not suitable for all NTP deployments. It is not an extensible mechanism and introduces some semantic confusion throught the use of the "SNTP" acronym. Additionally the approach of only offering IPv6 addresses to specify Server location does not meet NTP requirements that make use of a FQDN (Fully Qualified Domain Name) as well. For all the abovementioned reasons, this document makes deprecated.

section.t: When this document is published, the IANA is requested to mark option OPTION_NTP_SERVER (56) from "DHCP Option Codes" registry as obsolete.
